turns.speaker: ROBERTO
turns.text: Your good heart in helping the poor widow has shamed me, and I want to show that I, too, have some Christian charity.  Her rent will remain what it was.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: ROBERTO
turns.text: In fact, reduced, bu five dollars!

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: I accept your generosity...

turns.speaker: ROBERTO
turns.text: I won't keep you another minute...

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Thanks, doll.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I say let loverboy watch his movie.  And be grateful Boone's not cutting Shirley Temple's lawn.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Why is everybody giving me crap tonight?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What makes you say that?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Just thinking out loud.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah, well keep your filthy thoughts to yourself.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: All right, then.  He's interested in you for your conversation.  We know what a great talker you are.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Fuck you.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Not anymore you don't.  Doll.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: We're watching the movie, Harry. You got that!  We are watching my fucking movie.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: This looks corny.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Go wash glasses if you don't like it.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: These old movies are such a hoot. They thought they were being scary, but they're just funny.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe it's supposed to be funny.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Funny is funny and scary is scary. You don't mix them.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: So what did you think?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Weird.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You know what?  I think you guys are all jealous.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What's to be jealous of?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I've gotten to know someone who's famous.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Not so famous any of us have ever heard of him.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: If he were that famous, he probably wouldn't give me the time of day. This way, he's like <u>my</u> famous person.  Yeah, my own personal famous person.  Who treats me like I'm somebody worth talking to.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What's that mean?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It means it's too cold to go swimming.  And I don't mean the water.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I wasn't going to try anything.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Yeah, and I'm never going to smoke another cigarette.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: This old guy -- he's the kind of person I expected to meet when I moved out here.  Someone who's done things with his life.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Do you realize you're more interested in this old goober than you ever were in me?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's different.  He's a man.  And by the way you have no business calling him a homo.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It never crossed your mind?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: He's an artist.  Anyway, he's too old to think about sex.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: All the old men I know think about nothing but sex.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You picked up that girl right in front of me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Hey, no strings, right?  That's what you always said.  Just good pals who have the hots for each other.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: It still hurt.  A lot.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I didn't mean to...

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No, I'm actually kind of glad it happened.  It made me wonder what the hell I was doing with my life. Letting you pull me into bed whenever the spirit moved you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You liked it too.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Sure.  I loved it.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: If you enjoy it, you should do it.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: You know, I just can't do that anymore.  I still have time to get things right.  Get married again --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You mean us?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: The look on your face!  You're not marriage material.  You're not even boyfriend material.  You're a kid. A big, fun, slightly irresponsible kid.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not a kid.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What are you then?  What will you be ten years from now?  Still cutting lawns?  Still banging horny divorcees in your trailer?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I like my life.  I'm a free man.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Sure you're free, for now at least. But how long before you're just alone?  Pathetic and alone.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: So you don't want to fuck.  That's what you're telling me?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Is that all this conversation means to you?  Am I going to put out or not?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Damn straight.  I'm sick of playing games.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Don't worry, you already paid me. I'm here because --

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: The Master is waiting for you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's your job, lady, not mine.  I'm here so he can draw my picture.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: I'm keeping away.  What you are doing is no business of mine.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What're you talking about?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: What kind of man are you?  Are you a good man?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah, I'm a good man.  Something make you think I'm not?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You will not hurt him?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Gimme a break.  I'm going to sit on my ass while he draws pictures.  Is that going to hurt him?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  No.  I am sorry.  Forget everything I say.  Here.  I will take the tray.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You do that.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Something I can do for you?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: The Master wants to know if you are free for lunch.  I tell him you will be having other plans, but he insists I ask.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Got a lawn this afternoon, but I'm free until then.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Expect nothing fancy.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: The Master is dressing.  I am to offer you a drink.  There is whiskey and there is iced tea.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Tea is fine.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  You are a guest now.  You go in the living room.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's okay, Hanna.  I'm more comfortable in here.  It is Hanna, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: How long you worked for Mr. Whale?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Long enough.  Fifteen years.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I bet you've seen a lot of famous people come and go?  Movie stars?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  We live simply, Mr. Jimmy and I.  People come to play bridge. And now and then, young men to swim.  You have people, Boone?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You mean family?  All in Joplin, Missouri.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Your wife?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not married.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Oh, I don't know.  Because no girl in her right mind will have me?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: A man who is not married has nothing.  He is a man of trouble. You need a woman.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You proposing what I think you're proposing?  Don't you think I'm a little young for you?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You ever been married, Hanna?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Of course.  I am married still.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah?  What's your husband do?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: He is dead now, twenty years.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Then you're as single as I am.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  I have children, grandchildren too.  I visit when I can.  But now that Mr. Jimmy cannot be left very long, I do not get away much.  Poor Mr. Jimmy.  There is much good in him, but he will suffer the fires of hell.  Very sad.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're sure of that?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: This is what the priests tell me. His sins of the flesh will keep him from heaven.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sins of the flesh?  Everybody has those.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  His is the worse.  The unspeakable.  The deed no man can name without shame?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: What is the good English?  All I know is bugger.  He is a bugger. Men who bugger each other.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: A homo?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Yes!  You know?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: That is why he must go to hell.  I do not think it fair.  But God's law is not for us to judge.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're telling me Mr. Whale is a homo.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You did not know?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Well...no, not really --

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You and he are not doing things?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Good.  That is what I hope.  I did not think you a bugger too.  I fear only that you might hurt him if he tries.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not going to hurt anyone.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Yes.  I trust you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's not what you think.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: I have brought you your clothes. All I ask is that you get dressed and go.  We are having a guest for breakfast.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I need to talk to you about Mr. Whale.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: There is nothing you can say that will surprise me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe.  But I still need to talk. Do I have time for a cup of coffee before I go?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: I blame my daughter for keeping me out so late.  I only hope you did not get him excited.  It could give him a new stroke.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Thanks.  Why do you do it?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: What do I do?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Take care of Mr. Whale like he was your flesh and blood.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: It is my job.  I did it when he was happy and it was easy.  It is only fair I do it now when he is ill.  Enough talk.  I must wake up the master.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: What have you done with him?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I put him to bed.  He's not there?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I didn't do it.  This wasn't me.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Jimmy.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: He wanted me to kill him, but I didn't.  He did it himself.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: He says here good-bye.  I find it in his room.  He is sorry, he says. He has had a wonderful life.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You must leave.  You were not here this morning.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But I didn't do this!

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: The police will not know that. They will want to investigate.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: We have his note.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Do you want to be questioned about you and Mr. Jimmy?  Please, Clayton.  It will be better if I find the body alone.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But how're you going to explain this?  How did you get him out of the pool?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You are right.  Yes.  We must put him back.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Mornin'.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: My name is Whale.  This is my house.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Nice place.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: And your name is --?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Boone.  Clayton Boone.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I couldn't help but notice your tattoo.  That phrase?  Death Before Dishonor.  What does it mean?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just that I was in the Marines.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: The Marines.  Good for you.  You must have served in Korea.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Getting to be a warm day.  A scorcher, as you Yanks call it.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah.  I better get on with my work.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Everything alright, Mr. Boone?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just got away from me.  Sorry to disturb you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I was just about to ask Hanna to bring down iced tea.  I'd like it very much if you'd join me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I stink to high heaven right now.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: The honest sweat of one's brow.  I assure you I won't be offended. Let me tell Hanna to bring tea for two.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Or would you prefer a beer?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.  Iced tea's fine.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Splendid.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: These are your paintings?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What?  Oh yes.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Excuse me, but -- are you famous?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You know what they say.  If you have to ask --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm just a hick who cuts lawns. But some of these look familiar.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: They were familiar when I painted them.  That one's copied from a Dutch still life done almost three hundred years ago.  And that's a Rembrandt.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: They're just copies then.  Gotcha.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But before I retired, you might say I had a brief time in the sun. Fame, as it were.  Tell me, do you like motion pictures?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sure, everybody does.  When I was a kid I'd go with my sister twice a week.  Why?  Were you an actor or something?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: In my youth, yes, but never in Hollywood.  No, I was merely a director here.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah?  What were some of your movies?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: This and that.  The only ones you maybe have heard of are the "Frankenstein" pictures.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: "Frankenstein" and "Bride of" and "Son of" and all the rest?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I made only the first two.  The others were done by hacks.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Still.  You must be rich.  Making a couple of famous movies like those.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Merely comfortable.  Here's Hanna with our refreshments.  Can you get the door?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: When they stay in your employ too long, servants begin to think they're married to you.  Please, Mr. Boone.  Help yourself.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What did she mean by going flooey?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I returned recently from a stay in hospital.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What was wrong?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Nothing serious.  A touch of stroke.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You must excuse me for staring, Mr. Boone.  But you have a marvelous head.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: To an artistic eye, you understand. Have you ever modeled?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You mean, like posed for pictures?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Sat for an artist.  Been sketched.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What's to sketch?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You have the most architectural skull.  And your nose.  Very expressive.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Broke is more like it.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But expressively broken.  How did it happen?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Football in college.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You went to university?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just a year.  I dropped out to join the Marines.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes.  You were a Marine.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I apologize for going on like this. It's the Sunday painter in me.  Of course I can understand your refusal.  It's a great deal to ask of someone.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You mean -- you really want to draw me?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Indeed.  I'd pay for the privilege of drawing your head.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But why?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Even an amateur artist needs a subject to inspire him.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: And it's just my head you want? Nothing else?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What are you suggesting?  You'll charge extra if I include a hand or a bit of shoulder.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You don't want to draw pictures of me in my birthday suit, right?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I have no interest in your body, Mr. Boone.  I can assure you of that.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right then.  Sure.  I could use the extra dough.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Excellent.  We'll have a most interesting time.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Did you see this?  They're showing one of your movies tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You don't say?  Which picture?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: "Bride of Frankenstein."

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Hmmm.  I much prefer "Show Boat" or "The Invisible Man."  Shall we begin?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: That shirt, Mr. Boone.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's new.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  It's too white, too distracting.  Would it be asking too much for you to take it off?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not wearing an undershirt.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Pish posh, Mr. Boone.  I'm not your Aunt Tilly.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But it's just my face you want to draw.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh if it's going to make you uncomfortable...  Perhaps we can find something else for you to wear.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: We could wrap this like a toga around your shoulders.  Would that help you overcome your schoolgirl shyness?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right already.  I'll take it off.  Kind of warm in here anyway.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Take a picture, it lasts longer.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: That's exactly what I intend to do.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Would you be more comfortable barefoot?  Feel free to remove your boots and socks.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.  I'm fine.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It's a bit like being at the doctor, isn't it?  You have to remain perfectly still while I examine and scrutinize you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Dripping?  Do you ever eat dripping in this country?  The fat from roasts and such, congealed in jars.  Used like butter on bread.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sounds like something you feed the dog.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It is.  Only the poorest families ever ate it.  We kept ours in a crockery jar.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Your family ate dripping?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course not.  As I said, only poor people --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I've just realized how terribly ironic it all is.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I've spent most of my life outrunning my past.  Now it's flooding all over me.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: There's something about the openness of your face that makes me want to speak the truth.  Yes, my family ate dripping.  Beef dripping and four to a bed, and a privy out back in the alley.  Are you also from the slums, Mr. Boone?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: We weren't rich.  But we weren't poor either.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No, you were middle class, like all Americans.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I guess you'd say we lived on the wrong side of the tracks.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: In Dudley there were more sides of the tracks than any American can imagine.  Every Englishman knows his place.  And if you forget, there's always someone to remind you.  My family had no doubts about who they were.  But I was an aberration in that household a freak of nature.  I had imagination, cleverness, joy.  Where did I get that?  Certainly not from them.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You have to excuse me, Mr. Boone. Since my stroke, I am often overcome with nostalgia.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't mind.  I'm not crazy about my old man either.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: How are you, Mr. Boone?  So glad you are free for lunch.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right, I guess.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I assume you worked up an appetite with your labor.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Do you mind?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Is this David's doing?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: This David's a friend?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes.  An old, useless friend.  You must excuse me, Mr. Boone.  This is a world I finished with long ago. I pay them no mind and expect them to return the compliment.  Lunch should be ready.  Shall we?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Saw your movie the other night. Watched it with some friends.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Did you now?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I liked it.  We all did.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Did anyone laugh?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Pity.  People are so earnest nowadays.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Why?  Was it supposed to be funny?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course.  I had to make it interesting for myself, you see.  A comedy about death.  The trick is not to ruin it for anyone who isn't in on the joke.  But the Monster never receives any of my gibes.  He is noble.  Noble and misunderstood.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Did you kill anyone?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't like to talk about that.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It's nothing to be ashamed of, in the service of one's country. That's something to be proud of.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Proud?  Any jerk with a gun can kill someone.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Quite true.  Hand-to-hand combat is the true test.  Did you ever slay anyone hand-to-hand?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.  I could have, though.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes, I believe you could.  How free is your schedule this afternoon?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Full up.  I got the hedges to do here, then another lawn out by La Cienega.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What is we say phooey to the hedges?  Could you spare an hour after lunch?  To sit for me?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Can't today.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'll pay our going rate.  Plus what you'd get if you did the hedges.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sorry.  I don't feel like sitting still today.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: All righty.  I understand.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Just a trim.  And mine while you're at it.  Fingers are a bit stiff today.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You ever been married, Mr. Whale?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No.  At least not in the legal sense.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: So you had a wife?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Or a husband.  Depending on which of us you asked.  My friend David. He lived here for many years.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Does that surprise you?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No, I -- you're a homosexual.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh dear.  If one must have a clinical name.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not, you know.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I never thought you were.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You don't think of me that way, do you?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What way might that be?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You know.  Look at me like -- like I look at women.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous.  I know a real man like you would break my neck if I so much as laid a hand on him. Besides, you're not my type.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: So we understand each other?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What you do is no business of mine. Live and let live, I say.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I hope this has nothing to do with your refusing to sit for me today?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.  I --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Can I see what you did so far?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It will only make you self-conscious.  You'll have to remove your shirt.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sorry.  Not today.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But we have to match the other sketch.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I just feel more comfortable keeping it on.  You just said you didn't want me self-conscious.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh dear.  I <u>have</u> made you nervous.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm fine.  I'd just rather keep it on.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Suppose we unbutton the top and pull it down around your shoulders? Two buttons.  Is that so much to ask?  Just two little buttons.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't mean to be a prick, but that's how I feel.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course.  I don't want to scare you off.  Not before I'm finished with you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Tell me more about yourself, Mr. Boone.  You have a steady companion?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Not at the moment.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You know how it is.  You have to kiss ass just to get a piece of it.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Very well put.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The world is just one kiss-ass game after another.  A man has to make up his own life, alone.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Ah.  A philosopher.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Thoreau with a lawnmower.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I like that.  But take care, Mr. Boone.  Freedom is a drug, much like any other.  Too much can be a very bad thing.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Is that why you and your friend split up?  Because you wanted to be free?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: In a way, yes.  I suppose so.  I know it's why I stopped making pictures.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You might not think it to look at me now, but there was a time when I was at the very pinnacle of my profession.  The horror movies were behind me.  I'd done "Show Boat." Major success.  Great box office. Now I was to do something important.  "The Road Back."  An indictment of the Great War and what it did to Germany.  It was to be my masterpiece.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: The fucking studio butchered it. It was 1937, Hitler's armies were already massing -- and still the New York bankers stood in line to curry his favor.  Anything to avoid losing the German market.  They cut away the guts and brought in another director to add slapstick. The picture laid an egg, a great expensive bomb.  For which I was blamed.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: After that, I went out of fashion. I was no longer able to command the best projects, so I walked away.  Why should I spend my time working in such a dreadful business?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Do you miss it?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It's so far in the past now.  Over fifteen years --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I think we all want to feel we've left our mark on the world.  Yes. I wish I had done more work.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You've done a helluva lot more than most people.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Better work.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But I chose freedom.  David was still in the thick of it, his life full of anxiety and studio intrigue.  I didn't fancy spending my golden years as merely "the friend."  The dirty little secret of a nervous producer.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: How long were you...?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Twenty years.  Too long.  We were like a play whose run outlasted the cast's ability to keep it fresh. So I finally decided to close down the show.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course, they weren't nearly as bashful.  No, this room was once filled with bare buttocks.  And pricks.  Hard, arrogant pricks --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Cut it out!

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Isn't it enough you told me you're a fairy?  Do you have to rub my nose in it?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I assure you, Mr. Boone, I meant no --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: From now on, Mr. Whale, I cut your grass and that's it.  Understand?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: The extras are in their places. Now we need the star.  Wouldn't you like to get in the pool?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You first.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh no.  I never swim.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Mr. Boone.  You're not due to cut the lawn until Wednesday.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'd like to sit for you again.  But only if you ease up on the locker room talk.  Okay?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'm curious, Mr. Boone.  What convinced you to come back?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't know.  I guess I like your stories.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Everybody has stories to tell.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Not me.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What about your stint in Korea? I'm sure it was full of dramatic episodes.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I told you.  I don't like to talk about that.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: And the fear you showed at our last session?  How did you overcome that?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Not fear.  More like disgust.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Same difference, Mr. Boone. Disgust, fear of the unknown -- all part of the great gulf that stands between us.  Am I right in assuming that you've had little experience with men of my persuasion?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: There's no people like you in my crowd.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No teammates in football?  No comrades in Korea?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You must think the whole world is queer.  Well it's not.  War sure isn't.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, there may not be atheists in the foxholes, but there are occasionally lovers.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're talking through your hat now.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Not at all.  I was in the foxholes myself.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You were a soldier?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I was an officer.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: This was World War I?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No, my dear.  The Crimean War. What do you think?  The Great War. You had a Good War, while we had --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Barnett.  Was that his name? Leonard Barnett.  He came to the front straight from Harrow.  And he looked up to me.  Unlike the others, he didn't care that I was a workingman impersonating his betters.  How strange, to be admired so blindly.  I suppose he loved me.  But chastely, like a schoolboy.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Something happened to him?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You will not set me on another walk down memory lane.  Not this lane. Not today.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I didn't --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Why do I tell you this?  I never told David.  I never even remembered it until you got me going.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're the one who started it.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You're very clever, Mr. Boone.  You just sit there and let me talk. What a sorry old man, you're thinking.  What a crazy old poof.  Why are you here?  What do you want from me?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You asked me to model.  Remember?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course I remember.  Do you think I'm so senile --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Just go.  Please.  Why don't you go?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't get it.  First you creep me out with homo shit.  Then you hit me with war stories.  And now you're upset because I listen? What do you want?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I want -- I want...

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: My apologies.  I had no business snapping at you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No harm done.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It was foolishness to attempt this portrait.  You cannot force what will not flow.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You don't want me to sit for you anymore?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: If you don't mind driving, I'd like to take you as my guest.  There should be lots of pretty starlets to keep you amused.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm game.  Sure.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Very good, Clayton.  May I call you Clayton?  Or do you prefer Boone?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Clayton is fine.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Good afternoon, Clayton.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Do I look okay?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I suppose you'd like the top down.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: If that's okay?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Nothing would please me more.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What did I tell you?  Listen.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't hear anything.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Exactly.  Cukor was too cheap to hire music.  There's nothing but chin-wag.  The cold dreary custard of English chin-wag.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What was that about?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Nothing of importance.  Just two old men slapping each other with lilies.  Shall we have a drink?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: David.  The friend I thought was in New York.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.  The girl.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Girl?  Oh.  Elizabeth Taylor.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Is that really her?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: David produced her last picture.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Are you enjoying yourself?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Actually, no.  I feel a little out of place.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Neither of us really belongs here.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Must have been funny for you. Seeing your monsters again.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Monsters?  The only monsters...  ...are here.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Oh fuck.  And we left the top down. You want to run for it?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Run for what?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Can't you see?  It's raining!

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Let's get out of this funk hole

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You don't want to wait it out? Rain should let up soon.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: We're not sugar.  We won't melt.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I better get you home before you catch your death from pneumonia.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Catch my death.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It's not like her.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just a night out.  Sounds like she can't say no to her daughter.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Certainly you have better things to do than babysit an old man?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Good.  Let's get dry.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, of course.  Clayton.  You finished your shower already?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Ten minutes ago.  Didn't you hear me calling?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'm afraid not.  Terribly sorry.  I believe I promised you some clothes.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You're much wider than I am.  You won't want to attempt to get into my pants.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No.  Definitely not.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: That only leaves the rest.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You don't have any baggy shorts? Pajama bottoms?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Sorry.  My pajamas are tailored. Would it be too distressing to continue with the towel?  No more immodest than a kilt, you know.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Do I have any other choice?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Very sporting of you, Clayton.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Is that --?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: The only memento I ever kept.  My original sketch for the Monster.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: After dinner, if Hanna isn't back? Can we try a few more sketches?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I thought you'd given up on my picture.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'd like to try again.  If you're game.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Why not?  Give us something to do while we wait.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Tell me something, Clayton.  Do you believe in mercy killing?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Never gave it much thought.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Come now.  I'm sure you came across such situations in Korea.  A wounded comrade, or perhaps one of the enemy?  Someone for whom death would be a blessing.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I never made it to Korea.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But you said --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: -- that I was a Marine.  Which is true.  You filled in the rest.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: My old man was a Marine.  He enlisted the day he turned seventeen.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: The Great War?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: By the time he was ready to ship out, the fighting was over.  He missed out.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: A very lucky thing indeed.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's not the way he saw it.  To him, it was like his life never got started.  Nothing else really mattered.  Definitely not his family.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The morning after Pearl Harbor, he drove down to St. Louis to reenlist.  He was so damn excited. World War II was going to be his second chance.  They told him he was too old...fat ...nearsighted.  Said he'd be more use to his country if he stayed home and looked after his family.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Is that why you joined the Marines? For your father's sake?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I figured he'd think, you know -- it was the next best thing.  Hey, I loved it too.  A chance to be a part of something important. Something bigger than yourself.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I didn't have the guts for it.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You know what he did when I called him?  He laughed.  He laughed so hard he practically burst a blood vessel.  Said it was a good lesson for me.  Not to try to fill his shoes.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'm very sorry.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Them's the breaks, right?  No war stories for this pup.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: That's where you're wrong, Clayton. You've just told one.  A very good story indeed.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Do you mind?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Not at all.
